{
  "article_text": [
    "for each partition @xmath1 of @xmath2 there is an irreducible module of the hecke algebra of type @xmath0 whose basis is labeled by standard tableaux of shape @xmath1 .",
    "this paper defines and analyzes nonsymmetric macdonald polynomials with values in such modules .",
    "the double affine hecke algebra generated by multiplication by coordinate functions , @xmath3-type dunkl operators , the hecke algebra and a @xmath3-shift acts on these polynomials .",
    "they appear as simultaneous eigenfunctions of the associated cherednik operators .",
    "there is a canonical bilinear form which pairs these polynomials with those arising from the reciprocals of the original parameters .",
    "the macdonald polynomials and their reciprocal - parameter versions form a biorthogonal set of the form .",
    "the values of the form are found explicitly .",
    "there are symmetric macdonald polynomials in this structure .",
    "they are labeled by column - strict tableaux of shape @xmath1 ( non - decreasing entries in each row , strictly increasing in each column ) .",
    "formulae for these polynomials in terms of nonsymmetric macdonald polynomials are derived and the values of the bilinear form are obtained in this case .",
    "there are analogous results for antisymmetric macdonald polynomials , which are labeled by row - strict tableaux .",
    "there is a hook - length type formula for the bilinear form evaluated at the minimal symmetric polynomial associated with @xmath1 .    in the study of one - variable orthogonal polynomials",
    "the very simple graph @xmath4 symbolizes the gram - schmidt process used to produce the polynomials . in the present multi - variable setting",
    "the yang - baxter graph displays how each macdonald polynomial is produced .",
    "each arrow corresponds to either an adjacent transposition or an affine step @xmath5 .",
    "this idea is developed in section 4 .    in section 2",
    "we give the basic definitions of the hecke algebra , its modules , and the machinery necessary to describe the leading terms of macdonald polynomials .",
    "section 3 begins with the simplest two - dimensional module associated to the partition @xmath6 of @xmath7 .",
    "we describe how the basic operations arise in this situation and thus motivate our general definitions .",
    "the rest of the section gives the definitions and proves the fundamental relations , notably the braid relations , for the vector - valued situation .",
    "a key part is played by the triangularity property of the cherednik operators with respect to a natural partial order on monomials .",
    "section 4 contains the description of the simultaneous eigenfunctions , the spectral vectors , the transformation rules for the action of the generators of the hecke algebra on the polynomials , and the yang - baxter graph .",
    "section 5 concerns the connected components of the yang - baxter graph modified by the removal of the affine edges .",
    "here we find the conditions under which the component contains a unique symmetric or antisymmetric polynomial .",
    "the bilinear form is defined and evaluated in section 6 .",
    "the method of evaluation relies on relatively simple calculations of the effects of a single arrow in the yang - baxter graph .",
    "the minimal symmetric polynomials are studied in this section .",
    "the hook - length formula for the bilinear form gives some information about aspherical modules of the double affine hecke algebra , a topic to be pursued in future work .",
    "the paper concludes with a symbol index and a list of basic relations for quick reference .",
    "consider the elements @xmath8 and @xmath9 verifying :    1 .",
    "@xmath10 2 .",
    "@xmath11 3 .",
    "@xmath12 for @xmath13 4 .",

    "this implies that one can compute them using the yang - baxter graph s : the spectral vector of @xmath34 is @xmath35_{1\\leq i\\leq n}$ ] .",
    "the nonaffine edges act by @xmath21 on the spectral vector and by @xmath36\\over \\zeta[i]}-1}$ ] on the polynomials .",
    "the affine edges act by @xmath9 on the spectral vector and by @xmath37 on the polynomial .",
    "note that there exists a shifted version .",

    "@xmath47=0,\\ , 1\\leq i , j\\leq n.\\end{aligned}\\ ] ]      a * tableau * of shape @xmath1 is a filling with integers weakly increasing in each row and in each column . in the sequel *",
    "row - strict * means ( strictly ) increasing in each row and * column - strict * means ( strictly ) increasing in each column . +",
    "a * reverse standard tableau * ( rst ) is obtained by filling the shape @xmath1 with integers @xmath48 and with the conditions of strictly decreasing in the line and the column .",

    "an arrow of the form    = [ shape = rectangle , draw ] ( x)(y )    will be called a * step*. the other arrows will be called * jumps * , and in particular an arrow    = [ shape = rectangle , draw ] ( x)(y )    will be called a * fall * ; the other jumps will be called * correct jumps*. + as usual a * path * is a finite sequence of consecutive arrows in @xmath482 starting from the root and is denoted by the vector of the labels of its arrows . two paths @xmath483 and @xmath484",
    "are said to be * equivalent * ( denoted by @xmath485 ) if they lead to the same vertex .",
    "we remark that when @xmath211=v[i+1]$ ] , the part 1 of definition [ glambda ] is equivalent to the following statement : @xmath486 is obtained from @xmath50 by interchanging @xmath487 $ ] and @xmath488=\\sigma_v[i]+1 $ ] where @xmath487 $ ] is to the south - east of @xmath487 + 1 $ ] , that is , @xmath489-\\ct_{\\mathbb t}[\\sigma_v[i]+1]\\geq2 $ ] .",
    "the following arrow is a correct jump    = [ shape = rectangle , draw ] ( x)(y )    whilst    = [ shape = rectangle , draw ] ( x)(y )    is a step .",
    "+ the arrows    = [ shape = rectangle , draw ] ( y)(x )    and    = [ shape = rectangle , draw ] ( y)(x )    are not allowed .",

    "\\label{pati}%\\ ] ] and @xmath623    this proposition shows that we can easily use the spectral vector @xmath455 instead of the pair @xmath624 for labeling the macdonald polynomials ( assuming that @xmath619 for a given vector @xmath126 and a given tableau @xmath50 ) .",
    "+ indeed , we showed that if @xmath455 is a spectral vector and @xmath495\\succ\\zeta[i+1]$ ] or @xmath495\\prec\\zeta[i+1]$ ] then @xmath625 is also a spectral vector .",
    "such an action is called a _",
    "permissible transposition_. if @xmath495\\nsim \\zeta[i+1]$ ] then @xmath626 is not a spectral vector .",
    "we use some of the ideas developed by @xcite see theorem 5.8 , p.22 .",
    "let @xmath627 be a decreasing partition .",
    "suppose @xmath628",

    "+ in the rest of the section , we investigate the dimension of the spaces @xmath770 .",
    "the dimension of such a space equals the number of permutations of the vector of the entries of @xmath679 multiplied by the number of tableaux @xmath50 appearing in @xmath771 .",
    "the first number is easy to obtain but for the second we need to introduce some results of okounkov and olshanski @xcite :    suppose @xmath772 are partitions with @xmath773 ( @xmath774   \\leq\\lambda\\left [   i\\right ]   $ ] for all @xmath54 ) , @xmath775 then the set @xmath776   < j\\leq\\lambda\\left [   i\\right ]   \\right\\ }   $ ] is the skew - diagram @xmath777 .",
    "the basic step in determining the dimension of a connected component is to find the number ( denoted @xmath778 ) of rst s of shape @xmath777 , that is , the number of ways the numbers @xmath779 can be entered in @xmath777 so that the entries decrease in each row and in each column .",
    "there is an elegant formula due to okounkov and olshanski @xcite using shifted schur functions .",
    "writing @xmath780 to denote the determinant of the matrix @xmath781 , where @xmath782 ( the formula is independent of @xmath783)@xmath784 -i\\right )   _ { \\mu\\left [   j\\right ]   + m - j}\\right )   } { \\det\\left (   \\left ( m+\\lambda\\left [   i\\right]-i   \\right )   _ { m - j}\\right )   } , \\\\ \\dim\\left (   \\lambda\\backslash\\mu\\right )    &   = \\frac{s_{\\mu}^{\\ast}\\left ( \\lambda\\right )   \\left (   n - k\\right )   ! } { h\\left (   \\lambda\\right )   } , \\\\",
    "h\\left (   \\lambda\\right )    &   = \\frac{\\prod_{i=1}^{\\ell\\left (   \\lambda\\right ) } \\left (   \\lambda\\left [   i\\right ]   + \\ell\\left (   \\lambda\\right )   -i\\right ) ! } { \\prod_{1\\leq i < j\\leq\\ell\\left (   \\lambda\\right )   } \\left (   \\lambda\\left [ i\\right ]   -\\lambda\\left [   j\\right ]   -i+j\\right )   } , \\end{aligned}\\ ] ] where @xmath785 denotes the descending pochhammer symbol .",
    "note @xmath786 is version of the hook - product formula ( see @xcite p.11 ( 4 ) ) .",
    "also the denominator in @xmath787 is ( up to a sign ) the vandermonde determinant of @xmath788 + m - i,1\\leq i\\leq m\\right\\ }   $ ] giving the simplified formula @xmath789-i",

    "+ to each @xmath54 we associate the pair @xmath913=\\left(\\col_{\\std_1(t)}[i],\\row_{\\std_1(t)}[i]\\right)$ ] .",

    "we construct @xmath1187 and @xmath1188    here @xmath1189 $ ]    we have @xmath1190 where @xmath1191},\\dots , q^{\\mu_m},\\dots , q^{\\mu_2}s^{1-m+\\lambda[m-1]},\\dots ,   q^{\\mu_2}s^{2-m},q^{\\mu_1}s^{\\lambda[m]-m},\\dots , q^{\\mu_1}s^{1-m}].\\ ] ]    by telescoping we find @xmath1192})(1-q^{\\mu_j-\\mu_i}s^{j - i+\\lambda[m - j+1]})\\over ( 1-q^{\\mu_j-\\mu_i}s^{j - i})(1-q^{\\mu_j-\\mu_i}s^{j - i+\\lambda[m - j+1]-\\lambda[m - i+1]})}.\\ ] ]    first we compute @xmath1193 and following eq ( [ zetasink ] ) we write @xmath1194 with @xmath1195 } \\prod_{b=1}^{\\lambda[m - j+1]}{(1-q^{\\mu_j-\\mu_i+k}s^{j - i+b - a-1})(1-q^{\\mu_j-\\mu_i+k}s^{j - i+b - a+1 } ) \\over ( 1-q^{\\mu_j-\\mu_i+k}s^{j - i+b - a})^2}.\\ ] ] indeed , @xmath1196 splits into two factors : the first factor @xmath1197 does not depend on @xmath3 , all the factors of the second factor @xmath1198 involve @xmath3 . by",
    "telescoping we have @xmath1199}{(1-q^{\\mu_j-\\mu_i+k}s^{j - i+b - a-1})(1-q^{\\mu_j-\\mu_i+k}s^{j - i+b - a+1 } ) \\over ( 1-q^{\\mu_j-\\mu_i+k}s^{j - i+b - a})^2}=\\\\\\displaystyle { ( 1-q^{\\mu_j-\\mu_i+k}s^{j -     "this set splits into @xmath2 disjoint ( possibly empty ) sets : @xmath1249-y , 1\\leq z\\leq \\lambda[y ] , ( x - y - t)-(z - t)\\leq -2\\}.\\ ] ]    consider the partition @xmath690 $ ] then @xmath1250 hence , @xmath1251,[(1,2),(3,1)],[(1,2),(2,1)]\\}$ ] , + @xmath1252,[(1,2),(3,1)]\\}$ ] , @xmath1253\\}$ ] and @xmath1254 .    hence , @xmath1255\\in\\mathcal i_\\lambda}{(1-s^{x - y - z+t-1})(1-s^{x - y - z+t+1})\\over ( 1-s^{x - y - z+t})^2 } \\\\&=&\\displaystyle\\prod_{(x , y)\\in\\lambda}\\prod_{[(z_1,t_1),(z_2,t_2)]\\in\\mathcal e_{(x , y)}}{(1-s^{z_1-t_1+t_2-z_2 - 1})(1-s^{z_1-t_1+t_2-z_2 + 1})\\over ( 1-s^{z_1-t_1+t_2-z_2})^2 } , \\end{array}\\ ] ] and we recover ( [ ttwithnode1 ] ) .",

    "hence , @xmath1263-y}\\prod_{z=\\max\\{1,x+2-t\\}}^{\\lambda[y ] } { ( 1-s^{x - t - z+1})(1-s^{x - t - z-1})\\over ( 1-s^{x - t - z})^2 . } \\ ] ] by telescoping , we find @xmath1264-y}{(1-s^{\\max\\{1,x+2-t\\}-x+t-1})(1-s^{\\lambda[y]-x+t+1 } ) \\over ( 1-s^{\\max\\{1,x+2-t\\}-x+t})(1-s^{\\lambda[y]-x+t})}.\\ ] ]    we find also @xmath1265-y}{(1-s^{\\lambda[y]-x+t+1 } ) \\over ( 1-s^{\\lambda[y]-x+t})}={1-s^{\\lambda[y]-x+\\overline\\lambda[x]-y+1}\\over 1-s^{\\lambda[y]-x+1 } } = { 1-s^{\\hook_\\lambda[x , y]}\\over 1-s^{\\arm_\\lambda[x , y]}}\\ ] ] but if @xmath1266-y\\leq x$ ] then @xmath1267 for @xmath1261-y$ ] @xmath1268-y}{(1-s^{\\max\\{1,x+2-t\\}-x+t-1 } ) \\over ( 1-s^{\\max\\{1,y+2-t\\}-x+t})}=\\left(1-s\\over 1-s^2\\right)^{\\overline\\lambda[x]-y}.\\ ] ] if @xmath1266-y > x$ ] then we use telescoping to show @xmath1269-y}{(1-s^{\\max\\{1,x+2-t\\}-x+t-1 } ) \\over ( 1-s^{\\max\\{1,y+2-t\\}-x+t})}=\\left(1-s\\over 1-s^2\\right)^x{1-s\\over 1-s^{\\overline\\lambda[x]-a - b+1}}.\\ ] ] eq ( [ exy2 ] ) and ( [ exy3 ] ) give @xmath1270-y}{(1-s^{\\max\\{1,x+2-t\\}-x+t-1 } ) \\over ( 1-s^{\\max\\{1,y+2-t\\}-x+t})}=\\left(1-s\\over 1-s^2\\right)^{\\min\\left\\{x,\\leg_\\lambda[x , y]\\right\\ } } { 1-s\\over 1-s^{\\max\\left\\{1,\\leg_\\lambda[x , y]-x+1\\right\\}}}.\\ ] ] hence , from ( [ exy1 ] ) and ( [ exy4 ] ) we obtain @xmath1271\\right\\ } } { ( 1-s)\\left(1-s^{\\hook_\\lambda[x , y]}\\right)\\over \\left(1-s^{\\max\\left\\{1,\\leg_\\lambda[x , y]-x+1\\right\\}}\\right ) \\left(1-s^{\\arm_\\lambda[x , y]}\\right)}.\\ ] ] finally ( [ h2nabla ] ) , ( [ ttwithnode1 ] ) and ( [ exy5 ] ) give    @xmath1272\\right\\}}\\right.\\times\\\\&&\\displaystyle\\left . {",

    "y]};q\\right)_{\\leg_\\lambda[x , y]+1}\\over \\left(1-s^{\\max\\left\\{1,\\leg_\\lambda[x , y]-x+1\\right\\}}\\right ) \\left(1-s^{\\arm_\\lambda[x , y]}\\right)}\\right ] \\end{array}\\ ] ]    for a rational expression @xmath1273 let @xmath1274",
    ". here are some immediate consequences:@xmath1275   } s^{{\\rm ct}_{\\overline { \\mathbb t}}\\left (   i\\right )   } = q^{v\\left [   i\\right ]   } s^{-{\\rm ct}_{\\mathbb{t}% } \\left (   i\\right )   } = \\iota\\zeta_{v,\\mathbb{t}}.\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] if @xmath1276 then @xmath1277 if @xmath1278 then @xmath1279 . using this in the formula for @xmath1280",
    "we obtain@xmath1281 now suppose @xmath1 is a partition of @xmath2 and @xmath1282 are the tableaux corresponding to the minimal antisymmetric polynomial .",
    "for example @xmath1283 , then@xmath1284{ccc}% \\blue 0 & \\red 1 \\\\ \\blue 0 & \\red   1 & \\green 2 \\end{array } , \\mathbb{t=}% \\begin{array } [ c]{ccc}% \\blue 4 & \\red 2 & \\\\ \\blue 5 & \\red 3 & \\green 1 \\end{array } .\\ ] ]    as for symmetric polynomials , we set @xmath1285 our formulae show that@xmath1286   } \\left (   s\\right )   } % \\prod_{\\left (   i , j\\right )   \\in\\overline \\lambda}\\left (   qs^{-\\hook_{\\overline\\lambda}[i , j]};q\\right)_{\\leg_{\\overline\\lambda}[i , j]}\\\\ & = \\frac{\\phi_{n}\\left (   s\\right )   } { \\prod_{i=1}^{\\ell\\left (   \\overline \\lambda\\right )   } \\phi_{\\overline\\lambda\\left [   i\\right ]   } \\left (   s\\right )   } % \\prod_{\\left (   j , i\\right )   \\in\\lambda}\\left (   qs^{-\\hook_\\lambda[j , i]};q\\right)_{\\arm_{\\lambda}[j , i ] } ; \\end{aligned}\\ ] ] and thus    @xmath1287   } \\phi_{\\lambda^{\\prime } \\left [   i\\right ]   } \\left (   s^{-1}\\right )   } \\prod_{\\left (   i , j\\right ) \\in\\lambda}\\left (   qs^{\\hook_{\\lambda}[i , j ]   } ; q\\right ) _ { \\arm_\\lambda [   i , j ] } \\ ] ]    for the example @xmath1283,@xmath1288    note @xmath1289 does not always equal @xmath34 . for instance , @xmath1290",
    "throughout this paper , we have constructed and analyzed a macdonald type structure for vector valued polynomials , that is polynomials whose coefficients belong to an irreducible module of the hecke algebra .",
    "the `` classical '' macdonald polynomials are recovered for the trivial representation and then correspond to the shapes @xmath1291 , @xmath1292 .",
    "thanks to the yang - baxter graph we have found algorithms and some explicit formul   for computing the macdonald polynomials , their ( anti)symmetrizations , their scalar products _ etc . _ and give graphical interpretations of these properties . + we remark that almost everything works as for vector valued jack polynomials @xcite and that the jack polynomials are recovered as a limit case of macdonald polynomials as expected ( setting @xmath1293 and sending @xmath245 to @xmath34 ) .",
    "+ it remains to consider some constructions that could illuminate this theory .",
    "for instance , the shifted macdonald polynomials could be defined by slightly changing the raising operators . for the trivial representation , shifted macdonald polynomials are easier to manipulate than the homogeneous ones since they can be defined by vanishing properties @xcite .",
    "we have seen @xcite , that it is no longer the case for shifted vector valued jack polynomials for a generic irreducible module .",
    "but this research is not completed , and we speculate that the vanishing properties arise when considering some polynomial representations of the hecke algebra . + comparing the results in @xcite and @xcite , we find similarities between the concepts of singular non - symmetric macdonald polynomials and highest weight symmetric macdonald polynomials .",
    "we hope that this similarity extends to vector valued polynomials . in this context",
    ", minimal symmetric polynomials should play a special role and , perhaps , provide applications to the study of the fractional quantum hall effect .",
    "the fractional quantum hall effect is a state of matter with elusive physical properties whose theoretical study was pioneered by laughlin based on wave functions describing the many - body state of the interacting electrons .",
    "some of these wave functions ( called read - rezayi states @xcite ) are multivariate symmetric polynomials with special vanishing properties and it was shown , combining minimality of the polynomials for the vanishing properties and result of @xcite , that they are jack polynomials for a specialization of the parameter @xmath1294 ( see _ _",
    ". it would be interesting to know if we can identify other relevant wave functions from vector valued jack or macdonald polynomials .",
    "abc t. h. baker , p. j. forrester,_a @xmath3-analogue of the type @xmath1295 dunkl operator and integral kernel _ , int math res notices ( 1997 ) 14 : 667 - 686 arxiv : q - alg/9701039 . b. andrei bernevig , f. d. m. haldane , _ fractional quantum hall states and jack polynomials _ , phys .",

    "a.m.vershik , a.yu.okounkov , _ a new approach to the representation theory of the symmetric groups . 2 _ , zapiski seminarod pomi ( in russian ) v.307 , 2004 arxiv : math/0503040 .",
    "let @xmath294 then @xmath1303 for @xmath1304 and @xmath1305 for @xmath1306 .",
    "indeed @xmath1307 and@xmath1308 a consequence of the derivation is @xmath1309 the murphy elements are @xmath1310 .",
    "let @xmath1311 and @xmath1312 for @xmath69 , then @xmath1313 . for @xmath1314 both sides equal @xmath1315 .",

    "let @xmath1323   $ ] where @xmath1324 is an extension field of @xmath1325 ; on @xmath1326 there is a representation of @xmath1327:@xmath1328 where @xmath1329 ( @xmath144 is the transposition @xmath1330);@xmath1331 denote the multiplication operator @xmath1332 by @xmath1333 , @xmath65 , then@xmath1334"
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> this paper defines and investigates nonsymmetric macdonald polynomials with values in an irreducible module of the hecke algebra of type @xmath0 . </S>",
    "<S> these polynomials appear as simultaneous eigenfunctions of cherednik operators . </S>",
    "<S> several objects and properties are analyzed , such as the canonical bilinear form which pairs polynomials with those arising from reciprocals of the original parameters , and the symmetrization of the macdonald polynomials . </S>",
    "<S> the main tool of the study is the yang - baxter graph . </S>",
    "<S> we show that these macdonald polynomials can be easily computed following this graph . </S>",
    "<S> we give also an interpretation of the symmetrization and the bilinear forms applied to the macdonald polynomials in terms of the yang - baxter graph . </S>"
  ]
}
